question_text: Which statement best describes the central idea of the passage?
options: Technology is the primary driver of human knowledge.
The Wound Man was a mysterious figure whose origin and purpose remains unknown.
The Wound Man reveals the lack of knowledge that people in the Middle Ages possessed.
The Wound Man was a useful tool that aided both medical procedures and medical knowledge.

question_text: Which of the following statements best describe the function of paragraphs 1 and 2?
options: They provide an image of the Wound Man to help the reader visualize the object to be discussed in detail.
They convey the idea that the Wound Man was a terrible representation of life in the Middle Ages.
They highlight the grotesque monstrosity that reflected the brutal life of the Middle Ages.
They introduce the idea that life in the Middle Ages was difficult and filled with violence.

question_text: Which sentence from paragraph 1 and 2 best supports the idea that the series of descriptions are not those of a real human being?
options: “Staring impassively out of the page, he bears a multitude of graphic wounds.” (paragraph 1)

“His skin is covered in bleeding cuts and lesions, stabbed and sliced by knives, spears, and swords of varying sizes, many of which remain in the skin, protruding porcupine-like from his body.” (paragraph 1)
“His neck, armpits, and groin sport rounded blue buboes, swollen glands suggesting that the figure has contracted plague.” (paragraph 2)
“A dog, snake, and scorpion bite at his ankles, a bee stings his elbow, and even inside the cavity of his stomach a toad aggravates his innards.” (paragraph 2)

question_text: In paragraph 3, the word “alive” is used to highlight
options: how realistic the illustration appears to the viewer.
how dynamic and exciting life was in the Middle Ages.
how important the image is to medieval medicine.
how fortunate a person can be despite all the wounds.

question_text:
Read the following sentence from paragraph 4.

 A remarkable image of the Wound Man from Wellcome library depicts a figure that is penetrated not only by weapons but also by text.

How does this sentence fit into the overall structure of the passage?
options: It emphasizes the brutality of war in the Middle Ages.
It presents an explanation for the importance of the Wellcome Library.
It supports a previously made assertion about the role of the Wound Man.
It indicates that the Wellcome Library is the only place one can see the remarkable image of the Wound Man.

question_text: Paragraph 5 contributes to the development of the topic mainly by
options: listing the most typical disorders and physical problems encountered by most people in the Middle Ages.
providing examples of the ways in which Wound Men appeared in publications.
revealing that the Wound Men were at first limited to cures for spiders and treatment of arrow wounds.
demonstrating how limited the early Wound Men were in comparison to modern medical texts.

question_text: The author mentions the Wound Man’s “popular inclusion” in paragraph 6 mainly to
options: criticize the failure of most people to recognize the Wound Man’s importance.
support the claim that the Wound Man was well known to people of the Middle Ages.
emphasize the idea that the Wound Man was perceived to be a useful tool.
highlight the fact that the image of the Wound Man grew more complex over time.

question_text: Which sentence is the best summary of the impact the Wound Man had on helping us understand the Middle Ages?
options: By carefully listing all the types of cures, the Wound Man helped us modify our own medical practices.
It reminds us that war and violence has no place in the modern world.
Because of its specific references to various types of wounds and diseases, the Wound Man enabled us to gain a greater understanding of war.
It helps us to gain a greater appreciation of the technological advancements of the Middle Ages.

question_text: Which sentence best supports the idea that the Wound Man continues to have an important influence in society today?
options: “Despite this horrendous cumulative barrage of injuries, however, the Wound Man is very much alive.” (paragraph 3)

“Accompanying a text known as the ‘Wundarznei’ (The Surgery), these first Wound Men effectively functioned as a human table of contents for the cures contained within the relevant treatise.” (paragraph 4)

“It was living proof of the efficacy of the surgical enterprise, and a popular inclusion in medical works alongside a wide variety of related images that plotted diseases, the zodiac signs, bloodletting points, and anatomical schemes onto a similarly arranged human body.” (paragraph 6)

“Living on today in libraries from Copenhagen to Munich, the strange figure of the Wound Man gives modern viewers a glimpse of the worrying injuries that the medieval body could receive through war, accident, and epidemic.” (paragraph 7)

question_text: In paragraph 1, the phrase “rumor had it” is used to highlight
options: the dangers of consuming chocolate in the seventeenth century.
the miraculous effects chocolate was supposed to possess.
the unfounded claims that were not based on facts.
the belief that chocolate was considered food and not drugs.

question_text: The seventeenth-century European attitude toward chocolate was most influenced by
options: the brews of foreign beans.
wonder and danger of far-away lands.
pharmacists and physicians.
the abuse of hot beverages.

question_text: Which statement best describes professional reactions to chocolate?
options: They were generally positive, proclaiming its many health benefits.
They were generally negative, warning consumers about its potential for mischief.
They were mixed, resulting in competing evaluations about its usefulness.
They were generally ignored by the public, which prioritized taste over benefits to health.

question_text: How did Colmenero's work “enter the pharmaceutical annals” in Europe?
options: by using the descriptions of chocolate made by Cortés
by acquiring his degree in medicine from a Jesuit mission in the colonies
by contextualizing his work in a specialized branch of science
by acting as the main importer of chocolate

question_text: It can be inferred that Hippocrates would agree with which of the following statements?
options: Chocolate presents both the hot and cold characteristics.
Humoralism can be applied to the study of chocolates.
An excess of phlegm can lead to a sickness.
Fire is the strongest of all elements.

question_text: The author includes the details about “humoralism” in order to
options: describe the origin of European medicine.
explain how people develop sicknesses.
highlight the problems in the logic behind ancient medicinal theories.
reveal why ideas about chocolate were subject to disagreements.

question_text: Which statement best supports the idea that Colmenero had a large role in shaping the way people viewed chocolate?
options: “Colmenero's work dates from the era when Spain was the main importer of chocolate.” (paragraph 3)
“Colmenero's work introduced chocolate to Europe as a drug by appealing to the science of the humors, or essential bodily fluids.” (paragraph 3)
“Colmenero endeavored to make its mystery at least debatable in terms readily accessible across the countries of Western Europe.” (paragraph 5)
“Because Colmenero was a doctor and surgeon who was said to have traveled to the West Indies, his work was received as medical lore.” (paragraph 5)

question_text: Which sentence from the excerpt best shows that Colmenero's contributions were not limited to medicine?
options: “Chocolate was the first of the three to enter the pharmaceutical annals in Europe through Antonio Colmenero de Ledesma.” (paragraph 3)
“Colmenero's short treatise dates from the era when Spain was the main importer of chocolate.” (paragraph 3)
“Colmenero endeavored to make its mystery at least debatable in terms readily accessible across the countries of Western Europe.” (paragraph 5)
“It also supplied the very first recipe for hot chocolate on the European continent.” (paragraph 5)

question_text:
Read the following sentence from paragraph 5.

“Colmenero endeavored to make its mystery at least debatable in terms readily accessible across the countries of Western Europe.”

How does the sentence contribute to the development of the central idea?
options: It reveals Colmenero's argumentative personality that set off many debates in Western Europe.
It suggests that Colmenero wanted higher supplies of chocolate available to the people of Western Europe.
It identifies one impact of Colmenero's research.
It highlights the mystery chocolate caused among the people of Western Europe.

question_text: Which statement describes how the author’s use of sequencing in paragraph 3 contributes to the overall structure of the passage?
options: It shows that several people were simultaneously attempting to create an electric telegraph.
It shows how the invention of the electric telegraph depended on information and techniques discovered by others.
It shows that multiple means of long- distance communication were being used at the same time.
It shows how quickly long- distance communication changed from visual signals to electrical signals.

question_text: Which sentence is the best summary of how Morse obtained the funding necessary to build his telegraph system?
options: Morse’s application for a federal grant was delayed until 1843, so he spent time traveling in Europe, where he concentrated on obtaining a patent for his system.
Morse applied for a government grant that required both houses of Congress and the president to pass a bill awarding him $30,000 for his telegraph project.

Morse applied for a government appropriation and conducted telegraph demonstrations to show that his system could work, and after a delay caused by a financial depression, Congress approved the $30,000 appropriation in 1843.
Working with Gale and Vail allowed Morse to find flaws in Henry’s work and to develop his own ideas before applying for the federal government appropriation.

question_text:
Read this sentence from paragraph 7.

The desperate Morse gave the go- ahead, and the line was completed in time for the dramatic and spectacularly successful link between the Supreme Court chamber of the Capitol building and the railroad station in Baltimore.

The words “dramatic” and “spectacularly” in the sentence convey a
options: sense of relief and fulfillment that the line was finished.
sense of wonder and celebration that the telegraph line was accomplished.
feeling of excitement about the future possibilities of the telegraph.
feeling of confidence about being able to continue the work.

question_text: How does the graph support the ideas in paragraph 8?
options: It indicates how welcome the improvement of long- distance communication was in the United States.
It provides evidence of the dramatic increase in the number of telegraph messages as Morse’s system expanded across the United States.
It reveals that by the twentieth century millions of people had used the telegraph despite earlier hesitations about the system.
It shows how improvements that allowed Morse code to be read in real time made relaying telegraph messages faster and increased the system’s usage.

question_text: The idea that, in the mid- nineteenth century, the United States was mostly unaware of the possibilities of electricity is illustrated in the passage mainly through the
options: description of the government’s initial desire to expand a semaphore signaling system that used either flags or lights along the Atlantic Coast.
delay by the House of Representatives to pass the bill funding Morse’s telegraph line six years after he first applied for the appropriation.
discussions of the newly invented electromagnet that sparked the idea of sending codes through wires.
description of how an electric circuit could be closed to ring a bell at a distance.

question_text: With which statement would the author most likely agree?
options: Morse’s telegraph was successful because the wires were strung aboveground rather than underground as originally planned.
Understanding the importance of Morse’s telegraph requires detailed knowledge of electrical systems.
The implementation of Morse’s telegraph system was overly influenced by economic factors.
Morse’s invention of the telegraph made a great stride toward better connecting people across the United States and across the world.

question_text: How does the map provide additional support for a central idea of the passage?
options: by demonstrating that Morse’s telegraph system greatly exceeded the limitations of previous long-distance communication systems
by indicating that Morse was lacking foresight by seeking a patent only in North America
by proving that Gale’s advice helped Morse extend the telegraph’s range much farther than first thought possible
by showing that the Morse telegraph had a surprisingly immense influence across the world

question_text: The description in the first stanza (lines 1– 7) helps establish a central idea of the poem by
options: comparing the length of time the mountains have existed with the length of time the city has existed.
contrasting the grandeur of the mountains with the structures in the city below them.
implying that the mountains are a source of inspiration to the people in the city below.
suggesting that the mountains are larger than the people in the city realize.

question_text:
Read line 5 from the poem.

Pillars of the sky at rest

The line helps develop the theme of the poem by suggesting that the mountains
options: serve a noble and supportive purpose in the world.
attract the clouds with their strength and permanence.
remain untamed through the ages.
provide protection for the people.

question_text: How does isolating the word “Uprise” in line 7 affect the meaning of the poem?
options: It creates a contrast between the great plateau and the city buildings.
It reveals the similarity between the tall buildings in the city and the tall mountains on the horizon.
It creates a vision of the region before people developed the land.
It emphasizes that the mountains dominate the landscape.

question_text: Which line from the poem best supports the idea that people have sacrificed priceless natural beauty in order to make a profit?
options: “Above the dingy city- roofs” (line 3)
“The world makes war on them,” (line 10)
“Tunnels their granite cliffs,” (line 11)
“Plasters their cliffs with soap- advertisements,” (line 13)

question_text: How does the poet develop the speaker’s point of view in the second stanza (lines 8– 14)?
options: by describing images of the mountains’ awe- inspiring size and strength
by illustrating the differences among the various ways humans can affect the natural environment
by criticizing society for taking careless, harmful courses of action against nature
by demonstrating how the mountains and the people are able to benefit from each other

question_text: Which detail from the poem reflects the speaker’s view that people often fail to appreciate what is familiar?
options: “The mountains from the great plateau” (line 6)
“They have been here now for too long a time.” (line 9)
“Splits down their shining sides,” (line 12)
“To which the future is as was the past,” (line 18)

question_text:
Read lines 21– 22 from the poem.

Barrier broken down by those who do not need
The joy of time- resisting storm- worn stone,

How do the lines help convey the speaker’s point of view?
options: They suggest that the speaker wants to remove the obstacles that prevent others from experiencing the wonders of nature.
They reveal the speaker’s opinion that some people are too busy to appreciate natural beauty.
They reflect the speaker’s dismay that people destroy the natural landscape without understanding the ramifications of their actions.
They explain that the speaker is confident that nature will never be fully destroyed by people.

question_text: How do the details in the third stanza (lines 15– 26) most contribute to the development of a theme of the poem?
options: by reflecting nature’s capacity to resist change
by showing that nature is capable of influencing human will
by exposing how a lack of awareness leads to nature’s ruin
by explaining why people must respect nature

question_text:
Read lines 23– 26 from the poem.

The mountains swing along
The south horizon of the sky;
Welcoming with wide floors of blue- green ice
The mists that dance and drive before the sun.

The personification in these concluding lines of the poem suggests that the mountains are
options: gracious hosts who are untroubled by the actions of people.
unaware of their coming destruction.
lively entertainers who are amused by the everyday concerns of people.
too proud to reveal their pain.

question_text: What is the effect of comparing groups of bristlecone pines to “a city within a cemetery”(paragraph 2)?
options: It illustrates that the new tree’s appearance is markedly different from that of mature bristlecone pines.
It emphasizes the new tree’s ability to use resources left by prior generations of bristlecone pines.
It highlights the tree’s capacity for a long life if it is able to survive to maturity.
It reveals that the tree’s dense growth patterns are unusual in arid conditions.

question_text: In paragraph 4, the idea that the bristlecone pine can withstand difficult conditions is illustrated mainly through
options: a comparison of the bristlecone pine with similar trees that are known for their long lives.
a description of specific qualities of the bristlecone pine that make it suited to its environment.
an explanation of why the White Mountains are the best place for the bristlecone pine to grow.
an examination of why the bristlecone pine has few competitors in the White Mountains.

question_text:
Read this sentence from paragraph 5.

Empires rose and fell; wars raged; . . . and the tree from 2500 B.C. continued its implacable slow-motion existence, adding about two-hundredths of an inch to the diameter of its trunk each year.

The sentence contributes to the development of ideas in the excerpt by
options: emphasizing the bristlecone pine’s precise growth pattern.
suggesting that things that seem well established face threats.
describing the pace of the life cycle of the bristlecone pine.
explaining the reason for the bristlecone pine’s longevity.

question_text: Which claim is best supported by the details in paragraph 5 about the bristlecone pine’s treering record?
options: The bristlecone pine must be protected from extinction so that there is a record of changing Earth conditions.
The structure of the bristlecone pine allows scientists to predict changing Earth conditions over time.
The slow growth process of the bristlecone pine allows it to survive in spite of changing Earth conditions.
The bristlecone pine can be used to gather information on changing Earth conditions because of its long life.

question_text: The phrases “clings to life” and “stripped of bark” in paragraph 6 are used to highlight
options: that the tree is fragile and needs help to avoid becoming extinct.
how the tree can be misunderstood because of its appearance.
how the tree interests observers with its unusual appearance.
that the tree manages to survive even when partially fossilized.

question_text: The details in paragraph 7 convey a central idea of the excerpt by suggesting that
options: the success of the bristlecone pine lies in its ability to resist climate change.
the uncommon appearance of the bristlecone pine is related to its ability to survive.
the attachment that humans have to the bristlecone pine is understandable.
the longevity of the bristlecone pine continues to encourage experts.

question_text: What is the best summary of the bristlecone pine’s life cycle?
options: The bristlecone pine takes root as a stubby seedling in the mountains. Over time, it grows slowly in a hostile environment with alkaline soil that ensures little competition from other trees.
The bristlecone pine grows up slowly from the fragments of its dead ancestors. Over time, it begins to become contorted in appearance but continues to funnel water and nutrients to its stem.
The bristlecone pine grows slowly in an environment hostile to other trees. Over time, its trunk and some branches fossilize, but it funnels water and nutrients to other parts that are still alive.

The bristlecone pine grows only in one location in the mountains. Over time, it develops sparse foliage that fossilizes slowly, but the trunk and branches stay alive, as revealed by ribbons of live bark.

question_text: Throughout the excerpt, the author conveys his point of view mainly by
options: sharing details about the qualities of the bristlecone pine that make it an unusual tree
comparing the bristlecone pine to global empires that lasted thousands of years before falling.
explaining the way the seemingly sickly appearance of the bristlecone pine contrasts with its ability to survive.
arguing that the bristlecone pine has survived past threats to its survival and will continue to thrive

question_text: Which revision of sentence 2 uses the most precise language?
options: These are the people who spend their free time volunteering at animal shelters, helping with activities in community centers, or cleaning up parks.
These are the people who spend their free time helping others in numerous ways at a variety of places, events, or organizations that need support.
These are the people who spend their free time working at local establishments that help people, animals, or other groups in need of assistance.
These are the people who spend a lot of time volunteering at places where they can help people in many ways.

question_text: Which sentence should follow sentence 4 to introduce the main claim of the passage?
options: With that in mind, high school students should consider engaging in some form of regular volunteerism.
Fortunately for students, these benefits are guaranteed to produce both immediate and long-term results.
In fact, studies have confirmed that volunteerism can be beneficial for students, the family, and the community.
For this reason, high school students should learn about how helping others can strengthen their communities.

question_text: Which sentence is least relevant to the ideas presented in the second paragraph (sentences 5–10) and should be deleted?
options: sentence 6
sentence 7
sentence 8
sentence 9

question_text: Which of these would best follow sentence 12 and support the ideas presented in the third paragraph (sentences 11– 12)?
options: These students show that they are likely to be responsible, reliable, and helpful young adults. Admissions counselors know that character traits like these will benefit the applicants as well as whomever they interact with.

Volunteering can help students meet new people who can provide references and advice to the students when they are applying to colleges. It can also be an invaluable opportunity for students to meet possible future employers.

The counselors hope that young adults who demonstrate this behavior will go on to volunteer during their college years, working on campus in student government and leadership programs or serving in the community at hospitals, schools, and homeless shelters.
Many colleges are looking for students who are not just academically successful but who also work well with others and care about improving and serving surrounding communities.

question_text: Which concluding sentence should replace sentence 22 to provide the best support for the argument presented in the passage?
options: In every city, there are homeless shelters, food pantries, youth centers, and political campaigns that depend on the support and commitment of hardworking young people

Clearly, students who volunteer will experience a host of benefits, such as learning new skills, meeting interesting people, opening up opportunities for the future, and gaining a sense of satisfaction.
When students carefully evaluate their activities and prioritize volunteerism, they find a way to work it into their schedule and are soon encouraging their peers to do the same.

Whether they are seeking admission to college, preparing to enter the workforce, or simply looking to reduce stress, high school students who volunteer can help themselves as much as they help others.

question_text: Which sentence should be added after sentence 5 to introduce the main topic of the passage?
options: The construction of the Gotthard Base Tunnel was approved by Swiss voters in 1992 and was funded by tolls, fuel taxes, and government loans.
Leaders from several European countries attended the opening ceremonies for the Gotthard Base Tunnel, a Swiss tunnel.
The Gotthard Base Tunnel is the world’s longest and deepest railway tunnel, stretching 35.5 miles straight through the base of the Swiss Alps.
The Gotthard Base Tunnel continues to help reduce the number of freight trucks on the roadways in the Swiss Alps.

question_text: Which sentence should be added to follow and support sentence 7?
options: The tunnel- boring machine is helpful to tunnel builders in the modern era and has been an improvement over dynamite.
These enormous tunnel-boring machines function somewhat like a cheese grater, with the cutter head grinding slowly through rock and stone.
Engineers had considered making a tunnel under the mountains for many years, but it was impossible to do without modern tunnel- boring machines.
Different types of cutter heads are used with tunnel- boring machines depending on the geology of the area where the tunnel is being created.

question_text: Where should sentence 11 be moved in order to improve the organization of the second paragraph (sentences 6–11)?
options: to the beginning of the paragraph (before sentence 6)
between sentences 6 and 7
between sentences 8 and 9
between sentences 9 and 10

question_text: Which sentence presents information that shifts away from the main topic of the third paragraph (sentences 12– 16) and should be removed?
options: sentence 13
sentence 14
sentence 15
sentence 16

question_text: Which transition phrase should be added to the beginning of sentence 18?
options: Although the Gotthard Base Tunnel is mainly for freight trains,
With the Gotthard Base Tunnel taking ten years to complete,
Because of the successful completion of the Gotthard Base Tunnel,
As the number of trains using the Gotthard Base Tunnel increases,

question_text: Which concluding sentence should be added after sentence 18 to support the topic presented in the passage?
options: There is proof that underground tunnels such as the Gotthard Base Tunnel are beneficial to the economy of the surrounding area.
The Gotthard Base Tunnel is an extraordinary example of how human ingenuity and persistence can overcome great obstacles.
The completion of the Gotthard Base Tunnel shows that people can work together to achieve important goals.
The Swiss government is confident that the economic impact of the Gotthard Base Tunnel will be worth its construction cost.

passage:
(1) The International Space Station has been inhabited by crew members since 2000.
(2) Tourists will soon be allowed to pay for visits to the space station.
(3) Because the cost is $52–$58 million round trip, few people will be able to take advantage of the opportunity to have a vacation in outer space.
question_text: What is the best way to combine these sentences to clarify the relationship between ideas?
options: The International Space Station has been inhabited by crew members since 2000, but tourists will soon be allowed to pay for visits to the space station, which cost $52–$58 million round trip, so few people will be able to take advantage of the opportunity to have a vacation in outer space.

The International Space Station has been inhabited by crew members since 2000 and will soon allow tourists to pay for visits, but because the cost is $52–$58 million round trip, few people will be able to take advantage of the opportunity to have a vacation in outer space.

The International Space Station has been inhabited by crew members since 2000, but tourists will soon be allowed to pay for visits to the space station, though the cost is $52–$58 million round trip, so few people will be able to take advantage of the opportunity to have a vacation in outer space.

The International Space Station has been inhabited by crew members since 2000, and tourists will soon be allowed to pay for visits to the space station because the cost is $52–$58 million round trip, therefore few people will be able to take advantage of the opportunity to have a vacation in outer space.

passage: (1) To improve upon a skill, people typically train one skill at a time. (2) It would make sense that one should learn to walk before learning to run to someone who is learning a new skill. (3) Psychologists, however, are finding that this is not always the case. (4) Practicing several skills together, a process called interleaving, produces much better results than working one skill at a time.
question_text: Which sentence contains an error in its construction and should be revised?
options: sentence 1
sentence 2
sentence 3
sentence 4

passage: The Appalachian Trail is a really long trail that a lot of people do each year.
question_text: Which revision of the sentence uses the most precise language?
options: The Appalachian Trail is an extremely long trail that millions of people do each year
The Appalachian Trail is a 2,200- mile trail that more than a million people hike each year
The Appalachian Trail is a 2,200- mile trail that two million people hike each year.
The Appalachian Trail is a lengthy trail that a couple million people do each year.

passage: (1) Construction of the Eiffel Tower, an iron lattice tower in Paris, France, started in 1887. (2) Shortly after its construction was completed it served as the entrance to the World's Fair in 1889, which honored the 100th anniversary of the storming of the Bastille. (3) Over time, it becomes a popular tourist destination, attracting people from all over the world. (4) Although it is now an architectural icon, it was initially criticized by artists, who believed it was a monstrous construction that violated conventional principles of aesthetics.
question_text: Which pair of revisions need to be made in this paragraph?
options:
Sentence 1: Delete the comma after 'Tower'.
Sentence 3: Change 'becomes' to 'became'

Sentence 1: Delete the comma after 'Tower'.
Sentence 4: Change 'believed' to 'had believed'

Sentence 2: Insert a comma after 'completed'.
Sentence 3: Change 'becomes' to 'became'.

Sentence 2: Insert a comma after 'completed'.
Sentence 4: Change 'believed' to 'had believed'

A survey asked students what pets they have. Based on the results, the following statements are all true:

• 41 students have cats.

question_text: How many students were surveyed?

t

The width of a rectangle is 114 cm. The ratio of the length to the width is 3:2. What is the perimeter of the rectangle?
options: 190 cm
285 cm
380 cm

question_text: If 3n is a positive even number, how many odd numbers are in the range from 3n up to and including 3n + 6?

Using the approximation 2.54 centimeters = 1 inch, how many centimeters are in 3 feet 9 inches?

options: 1 kph
3 kph
5 kph

question_text: What is the least common multiple of 24, 20, and 15?

question_text: A paste used for highway billboards is made by mixing the following ingredients by weight: 3 parts powder, 3 parts water, 3 parts resin, and 1 part hardener. To cover 1 billboard requires 30 pounds of the paste. How many total pounds of the resin are required to cover 4 billboards?

The base of the pyramid above is a square and each triangular face has the same area. The side length of the base MNPQ is 8 centimeters. If the surface area of the pyramid, including the base, is 160 sq cm, what is the length of RS?

6 cm
